items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake Levels are beginning to fall, however further rain throughout today 26/11/2022, is expected to cause the lake and river levels to rise again. Flooding may affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 04:30 on 27/11/22 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 107 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

This flood alert remains in force due to high tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Saturday 26/11/2022, between 08:00 PM and 09:30 PM. Areas most at risk include the area around Bridlington lifeboat station and South Pier at Bridlington. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9am on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This flood alert has now been removed. We will continue to monitor the local water levels and weather closely and reissue the alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: The Saturday evening tide at 07:15 PM is forecast to be higher than normal due to the unsettled stormy weather and may cause spray overtopping of the defences.  Heavy rain and force 7 westerly winds are also forecast.  Flooding is possible at Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour between 06:45 PM and 08:00 PM on 26/11/2022.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous.  This message will be updated by 13:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

As a result of bad weather this evening, large waves are forecast to overtop sea defences with sea spray.  The large waves and the tidal surge will help to increase the water levels and the  forecast high water is between 08:00 PM and 09:00 PM on the 26th November with a total water level of 5.57mAOD at West Bay and a Force 7 westerley wind.  All times are local and refer to the high water times at West Bay.  mAOD is height above average sea level and for more detail please refer to your local tide tables.  Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Lyme Regis, Charmouth, Seatown, West Bay, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogdean Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell.   Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill areas. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Further rainfall is forecast today. Levels have stabilised on the Wey but will remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby road, the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Hints River gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. However, there is further rainfall forecast later on Saturday, 26/11/22, and into Sunday, 27/11/22, therefore the river levels are likely to rise again in response to this rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Sunday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. Levels are currently falling on the Chertsey Bourne but may rise and come out of banks again due to additional rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast for today.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but generally steady at the Willington and Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Saturday evening's tide is forecast to be higher than normal and could reach 2.47m due to unsettled weather.  Heavy rain and force 7 westerly winds are also forecast.  Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. Flooding is possible at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit between 08:00 PM and 09:00 PM on 26/11/2022. Weather conditions are expected to produce large offshore waves. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. This message will be updated by 13:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday evening, 26 November 2022. High water at Exmouth on Saturday is at 20:30pm, but times of high water will vary along the coast.  Expect tides to be around 27mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. These conditions are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.18mAOD, this is 0.27 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, TW Logistics, Gainsborough Railway Bridge and Beckingham Marshes. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 27/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00, 27/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise this evening, Saturday 26/11/2022, due to forecast rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Rye, including low lying land and roads around Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck and including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise on the River Seven due to forecast rainfall. Flooding is possible from this evening Saturday 26/11/2022, areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and its tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the East of Normanby. Rainfall is forecast this evening, Saturday 26/11/2022. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on Sunday 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Chetnole river gauge as a result of current rainfall over tonight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 21:00 tonight and into Sunday morning. We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. The flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showery rainfall, heavy at times, is forecast for the rest of Saturday and into early Sunday morning. We expect river levels to remain high into Sunday.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

The flood alert for the River Esk has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise this evening, Saturday 26/11/2022, due to forecast rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Esk, including low lying land in the Esk Valley and some minor roads. River levels are expected to remain high overnight and into Sunday, 27/11/2022. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on Sunday 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks Llanymynech peaked at 3.58m on 25/11/22.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast today. We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: River levels are high and rising on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to the rainfall this evening.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in the areas should consider taking action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 26/11/2022 and 21:00 Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible. However, exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. River levels will rise through the early hours of Sunday. From 05:00 27/11/2022 minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and gardens of riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart Pub, and at Hempstead Mill, Uckfield. From 09:00 27/11/2022, minor flood impacts could affect fields and gardens in Isfield. If rain continues over the River Uck on Sunday, property flooding could be possible. River levels might not begin to fall until the early hours of Monday. Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until Tuesday. Please install flood protection products in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them, and take proactive action to reduce the impacts of flooding. We may close our flood gate in the supermarket car park in Uckfield town centre on Sunday to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 27/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall Saturday evening, 26/11/2022, into Sunday morning. Flooding is expected from 4:00am Sunday, 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and around Balls Green and Ashurst.   
After tonight's rain, further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday, 27/11/2022. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond where required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
River levels are expected to rise as a result of persistent rainfall forecast from 11pm tonight and throughout tomorrow, Sunday 27 November. We expect river levels to respond to the overnight rainfall and remain high before responding to further rainfall tomorrow afternoon. River levels are likely to remain high for the next few days.
 
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible around the river from tonight for the next 24 hours.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary.

This message will be updated by 8am on Sunday 27 November, or as the situation changes.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 Saturday 26/11/2022 and 21:00 Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible. However, exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. River levels will rise through the early hours of Sunday. From 12:00 27/11/2022 minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and the gardens of properties at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. If rain continues over the River Adur on Sunday, property flooding could be possible. River levels might not begin to fall until midday Monday. Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels at Mock Bridge are unlikely to return nearer to normal until midweek. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please take proactive action to reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 27/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is higher than normal, but following the dry weather yesterday (25/11/22), it continues to slowly fall. Today, residual flood impacts affecting roads, cycle tracks and footpaths is expected. At Sandown, the river is now low enough to allow ditches around Fort Holiday Park to drain. However, by early afternoon (26/11/22) and into Sunday (27/11/22) further heavy rain (20-40mm) is forecast. The river will rise quickly in response to any rain and it will cause additional flooding impacts to land, gardens and roads. Should 40mm of rain affect the river, then property flooding may occur at Alverstone and Langbridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can operate. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday 27/11/2022, or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 Saturday 26/11/2022 and 21:00 Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible. However, exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. River levels will rise through the early hours of Sunday. From 06:00 27/11/2022 minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the River Ouse, including on Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge and eventually the Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills. If rain continues over the River Ouse on Sunday, property flooding could be possible and Barcombe Mills Road could become impassable. River levels might not begin to fall until midday Monday. Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels in Barcombe are unlikely to return nearer to normal until midweek. Please install flood protection products in Barcombe, if you have them, and take proactive action to reduce the impacts of flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 27/11/2022.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 26/11/2022 and 21:00 Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible, but exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. From 05:00 27/11/2022 flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 09:00 27/11/2022, flood impacts could also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 18:00 27/11/2022 flooding could also affect North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. If rain continues on Sunday, property flooding is possible. River levels might not begin to fall until Monday. Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels will be higher than normal until midweek. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 27/11/2022.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall Saturday evening, 26/11/2022, into Sunday morning. Flooding is expected from 5:00am Sunday, 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane, and around Robertsbridge.   
After tonight's rain, further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday, 27/11/2022. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Rother. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond where required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are high as a result of rainfall over the last week. River levels are expected to rise from persistent rainfall forecast from 11pm tonight and throughout tomorrow, Sunday 27 November. We expect river levels to respond to the overnight rainfall and remain high before responding to tomorrow afternoons rainfall. 
 
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible around Kinnersley Manor and Sidlow from 2am tonight, with areas further downstream including Brockham, Dorking, Leatherhead and Cobham later on tomorrow. River levels are likely to remain high in these areas for the next few days.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary.
This message will be updated by 8am on Sunday 27 November, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force. River levels are rising following the heavy and prolonged rainfall during the daytime of Saturday 26th November. Further rain is forecast for this evening, which is expected to clear the area from around 10pm. As catchments are wet, rivers will respond to this rainfall and levels are expected to remain high throughout the night and into Sunday morning.  
Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads close to the river although no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday 27th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall Saturday evening, 26/11/2022, into Sunday morning. Flooding is expected from 5:00am Sunday, 27/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road.   
After tonight's rain, further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout Sunday, 27/11/2022. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Eden and its tributaries. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond where required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 on 26/11/2022 and 21:00 on Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible. However, exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. River levels will rise through the early hours of Sunday. From 06:00 on Sunday 27/11/2022, minor flood impacts could affect Liss and Sheet. Minor flood impacts could affect Iping and Midhurst from 10:00 on 27/11/2022, and 18:00 on 27/11/2022 at Lodsbridge near Selham. If rain continues over the Western Rother on Sunday, property flooding could be possible. River levels might not begin to fall until Monday morning. Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels near Fittleworth may not return nearer to normal until midweek. Please install flood protection products at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth as a precaution, if you have them. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please take proactive action to reduce the impacts of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 27/11/2022.

Persistent rain is expected between 19:00 on 26/11/2022 and 21:00 Sunday (27/11/2022). Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible, but exact amounts and locations remain uncertain. From 05:00 Sunday morning (27/11/2022), flooding could affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and gardens of riverside properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including properties on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. If rain continues over the Combe Haven on Sunday (27/11/2022), property flooding in Crowhurst could be possible Sunday afternoon. River levels might not begin to fall until the early hours of Monday (28/11/2022). Next week is forecast to be drier, but river levels will be higher than normal until midweek. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 27/11/2022.

Sunday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 27/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by Thursday's high energy waves. Winds are strong Southerly Force 6. Waves are large. The weather increases tide table values by 0.11 m. The total forecast tide is 5.96 metres Chart Datum (2.91 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Sunday's midday tide is predicted to be 30cm lower and accompanied by smaller waves. Minor flood impacts are expected until Monday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest.  Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 27/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high following twice the monthly average rainfall in November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Rain is expected between 19:00 on 26/11/2022 and 21:00 on Sunday 27/11/2022. Up to 50mm, or nearly half a month's rain, could be possible. River levels will rise through the early hours of Sunday. By Sunday evening, the Aldingbourne Rife could be higher than its peak of last week. River levels will not begin to fall until Monday afternoon. A small number of riverside properties in Marshall Close and Lake Lane, Barnham could also be affected. Next week should be drier. Please install flood protection products in Barnham, if you have them. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and are routinely clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 27/11/2022.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible Saturday 26 November and overnight into Sunday 27 November. Rain has been falling in the area and river levels are rising. Further rain is forecast this evening and into the early hours of Sunday. Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected from 6pm Saturday 26 November till 6am Sunday 27 November. No flooding to properties is forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and this message will be updated on Sunday 27 November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible Saturday 26 November and overnight into Sunday 27 November. Rain has been falling in the area and river levels are rising. Further rain is forecast this evening and into the early hours of Sunday. Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected from 6pm Saturday 26 November till 3am Sunday 27 November. No flooding to properties is forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and this message will be updated on Sunday 27 November or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
The river level on the Washford River at Beggearn Huish is slowly falling but continues to remain above the flood alert level. The river may rise later today and early Sunday following the forecast rainfall. All other rivers are currently below levels of concern but may also rise. 
There is the possibility of showers, heavy at times, for the rest of Saturday with drier weather returning for Sunday and into next week. There is continued risk of flooding of low-lying land and roads into Sunday but the flooding of properties is not forecast. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 16:30 and is forecast to reach 5.1mAOD. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. This alert will be updated tomorrow morning 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Donyatt river gauge as a result of the current rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 21:00 tonight and into Sunday morning.  We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showery rainfall, heavy at times, is forecast for the rest of Saturday and into early Sunday morning. We expect river levels to remain high into Sunday.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force. River levels are rising following the heavy and prolonged rainfall during the daytime of Saturday 26th November. Further rain is forecast for this evening, which is expected to clear the area from around 10pm. As catchments are wet, rivers will respond to this rainfall and levels are expected to remain high throughout the night and into Sunday morning.  

Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads close to the river although no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday 27th November or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high and rising on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River following tonights heavy rainfall.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and rising on the Upper River Frome at Maiden Newton due to the heavy rainfall tonight.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations on the River Frome in Maiden Newton at Dorchester Road and Frome Lane areas.  There is also a risk of flooding at Lower Barton Farm in Charminster.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. However, there is further rainfall forecast later on Saturday, 26/11/22, and into Sunday, 27/11/22, therefore the river levels are likely to rise again in response to this rainfall
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Sunday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.19 m and has just peaked and now starting to fall. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.27 m and currently stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m and the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86 m. Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station when river levels allow.
There is the possibility of showers, heavy at times, for the rest of Saturday with dry weather returning for Sunday and into next week. Flooding of low-lying land continues and there is the risk of some flooding to roads later today and Sunday but property flooding is not expected. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.42 m and is currently stable but may rise later today after the forecast rainfall. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.98m and is stable. Pumping will take place at Currymoor when the river levels allow. 
There is the possibility of showers, heavy at times, for the rest of Saturday with dry weather returning for Sunday and into next week. Flooding of low-lying land continues and there is the risk of some flooding to roads later today and Sunday but property flooding is not expected. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

Continued bands of heavy rain have fallen onto saturated ground in the Upper River Witham catchment.  River levels remain high. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout Saturday 26th November with further rain forecast overnight Saturday into Sunday. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Sunday 27th November or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam and Frisby river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding of farm land and low lying roads in the Melton and Asfordby areas, including Station Lane Ashfordly including low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected in locations near the River Derwent, particularly low-lying land upstream of Malton today, Saturday, 26/11/2022 and tomorrow, Sunday 27/11/2022. Further rainfall is expected today, Saturday 26/11/2022, and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels continue to remain high on the Lower River Derwent due to recent rainfall. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Further rainfall is expected today, Saturday 26/11/2022 and river levels are expected to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the middle to lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially in the areas around Thrupp. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours from Thrupp down to Oxford.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Croxall river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Glaze catchment including Leigh and East Wigan
items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Glaze.
Further rain throughout the afternoon is expected to cause the river level to rise this afternoon peaking at 04:15 PM on 26/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around Moss, Hey, Bedford and Borsdane Brooks and their tributaries.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updatedas the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Recent heavy bands of rain have caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

River levels have risen at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and low lying land at Quedgeley / Stonebench. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks: Mythe 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. Upper Pound 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. Further rainfall is forecast tonight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides are due tonight Saturday 26/11/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 3.9m at 23:15 this evening Saturday 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.6m at 23:00 this evening Saturday 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting the racecourse and the Worcester County cricket ground. Predicted peaks:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.3m to 5.6m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. Diglis 3.2m to 3.5m Sunday evening 27/11/22. Worcester 3.5m to 3.8m Sunday evening 27/11/22. Saxons Lode 4.1m to 4.3m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is now operational. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.3m to 5.6m overnight Sunday into Monday morning, 28/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Sunday's early morning tide at 01:06 on 27/11/22 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Southerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.25 m. The total forecast tide is 5.11 metres Chart Datum (2.38 mAOD) at Portsmouth. On Thursday, high energy waves removed a significant amount of shingle at South Hayling. At Eastoke Corner, the beach crest remains very narrow. Whilst the next tide is not overly high, large waves could remove more material from the beach. As a result, for 30 minutes either side of high water, sea front gardens and roads nearest Eastoke Corner may experience minor impact flooding. On Sunday afternoon (13:15 on 27/11/22) the tide is lower and we do not expect impacts. However, in the early hours of Monday morning (01:45 on 28/11/22), the tide level is once again a little more elevated, so we may issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority over the condition of the beach. Avoid South Hayling at high tide. We will update or remove this message by 17:00 on 27/11/22.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been falling on the River Evenlode, but are still high on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock. This is as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Water may remain on roads and farmland however further flooding is not expected for the next 24 hours. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to remain high on the river Glyme over the next few days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but starting to fall slowly at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks Crew Green peaked at 5.5m yesterday morning, Montford peaked at 4.6m  this morning, Welshbridge peaked at 2.3m this afternoon, Buildwas peaked at 3.5m this afternoon, Bridgnorth 2.75m this afternoon.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 27/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Sandhurst river gauge.  High tides are due at 23:00 tonight, Saturday 26/11/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore and Sandhurst Lane. Base Lane, Sandhurst may also flood. A417 Over to Maisemore maybe closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.7m to 3.9m at 23:15 this evening Saturday 26/11/22. Gloucester 3.4m to 3.6m at 23:00 this evening Saturday 26/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been rising on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week especially around Islip. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue around Islip. We are expecting rain this afternoon (Saturday) and into Sunday. We expect river levels to continue very slowly rising for the next 12 - 24 hours.
We are  monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Sunday, or as the situation changes.

Sunday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 27/11/2022 may cause flooding, as the condition of the shingle beach has been impacted by Thursday's high energy waves. Winds are strong Southerly Force 6. Waves are large. The weather increases tide table values by 0.11 m. The total forecast tide is 5.96 metres Chart Datum (2.91 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minor flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Sunday's midday tide is predicted to be 30cm lower and accompanied by smaller waves. Minor flood impacts are expected until Monday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. As a precaution, please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 10:00 on 27/11/2022.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels are remaining high on the River Dee. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane is cut off. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 26/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Predicted peaks: Mythe 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22. Upper Pound 3.6m to 3.8m at 00:15 on Sunday morning, 27/11/22.    
Further rainfall is forecast tonight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and closing flood gates.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger. 
This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight into Sunday morning 27/11/2022.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10am on 27/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force. River levels are rising following the heavy and prolonged rainfall during the daytime of Saturday 26th November. Further rain is forecast for this evening, which is expected to clear the area from around 10pm. As catchments are wet, rivers will respond to this rainfall and levels are expected to remain high throughout the night and into Sunday morning.  
Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads close to the river although no flooding to properties is currently forecast. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 11am on Sunday 27th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is expected on Saturday 26 November and overnight into Sunday 27 November. Rain has been falling in the area and is causing the River Avon to rise. Properties and low lying areas in South Brent, Avonwick, Brushford and Manor House near Diptford Gara Bridge, Loddiswell and Aveton Gifford will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. We are monitoring river levels and this message will be updated on Sunday 27 November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon at South Brent, Avonwick and Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

Properties and low lying areas in South Brent, Avonwick and Aveton Gifford will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. items.description: River Brit at Newtown, and Southgate Old Mill, Beaminster
items.message: River levels are high and rising on the River Brit due to the heavy rainfall this evening.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations on the River Brit at Newtown, Southgate Old Mill and Beaminster.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
items.message: River levels are high and rising on the Upper River Frome at Maiden Newton due to the heavy rainfall tonight.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations on the River Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester.  Areas in Higher Frome Vauchurch, Frome Vauchurch, Cruxton, Frampton, Grimstone, Muckleford, Stratton, Bradford Peverell, Wrackleford, Charminster, Frome Whitfield, Wolfeton, Lower Burton and Cokers Frome are at risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 27/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
